(operational phase) | technical_service_provider = | contractors = | construction = 2016 | est = June 1, 2017 | decom = | length_mi = 1,172 | discharge = | discharge_bbl_d = 0.47 | diameter_mm = | diameter_in = 30 | pumping_stations_no = | pumping_stations = | website = {{url|www.daplpipelinefacts.com}} }} The '''Dakota Access Pipeline''' ('''DAPL''') or '''Bakken pipeline''' is a {{convert|1172|mi|km|adj=mid|-long}} underground [[oil pipeline]] in the United States. It begins in the [[Bakken formation|Bakken]] [[tight oil|shale oil fields]] in northwest [[North Dakota]] and continues through [[South Dakota]] and [[Iowa]] to the [[Oil terminal|oil tank farm]] near [[Patoka, Illinois]]. Together with the [[Energy Transfer Crude Oil Pipeline]] from Patoka to [[Nederland, Texas]], it forms the Bakken system. The $3.78 billion project was announced to the public in June 2014, and informational hearings for landowners took place between August 2014 and January 2015.{{cn|date=February 2018}} Dakota Access, LLC, a subsidiary of [[Energy Transfer Partners|Energy Transfer Partners, L.P.]], started constructing the pipeline in June 2016. Its minor partners were [[Phillips 66]], [[Enbridge]], and [[Marathon Petroleum]]. The pipeline was completed by April and its first oil was delivered on May 14, 2017.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-north-dakota-pipeline-pes-idUSKBN17L0BJ|title=East Coast refiner shuns Bakken delivery as Dakota Access Pipeline starts|last=Renshaw|first=Jarrett|date=2017-04-19|work=Reuters|accessdate=2017-05-11}} The pipeline became commercially operational on June 1, 2017.{{cite news | title = Dakota Access pipeline now in service |url=http://thehill.com/policy/energy-environment/335898-dakota-access-pipeline-now-in-service | first = Timothy | last = Cama | newspaper = [[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] | date = June 1, 2017 |accessdate=June 1, 2017}}{{cite news | title = Dakota Access pipeline starts transporting oil to customers | url = http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/dakota-access-pipeline-starts-pumping-oil-article-1.3212637 | agency = The Associated Press | newspaper = [[New York Daily News]] | date = June 1, 2017 |accessdate=June 10, 2017}} The pipeline has been controversial regarding its impact on the environment. As time went on, Indigenous nations around the country began opposing the pipeline, along with the [[Sioux]] tribal nations. Under the assertion that the pipeline would threaten sacred burial grounds as well as the quality of water in their area. A [[Dakota Access Pipeline protests|protest at the pipeline site]] in North Dakota, next to and on the Standing Rock Indian Reservation. This sparked a worldwide movement known as "Standing Rock" which brought nearly 15,000 people to oppose the pipeline during the winter months. == Description == The pipeline, which initially was described by local media as the Bakken pipeline, has a permanent [[easement]] of {{convert|50|ft}} and a construction right-of-way of up to {{convert|150|ft}}. The {{convert|30|in|mm|adj=on}} diameter pipeline is at least {{convert|48|in|m}} underground from the top of the pipe or {{convert|2|ft}} below any [[drain tile]]s.{{cite news|first=William| last=Petroski|title=Should farmers make way for the Bakken pipeline?|url=http://www.press-citizen.com/story/news/2014/08/22/farmers-make-way-bakken-pipeline/14426829/|date=August 25, 2014|accessdate=December 4, 2014|work=Press Citizen}} The pipeline is planned to carry {{convert|470000|oilbbl/d}} of crude oil "based on contractual commitments to date". {{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/02/us/north-dakota-oil-pipeline-battle-whos-fighting-and-why.html | title = North Dakota Oil Pipeline Battle: Who’s Fighting and Why | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | first = Jack | last = Healy | date = 2016-08-26 | accessdate = 2016-11-27}} The capacity may be increased up to {{convert|570000|oilbbl/d}}. The company estimated the pipeline would cost $3.78 billion, of which $1.4  billion would be invested in the [[North Dakota]] portion, $820 million in the South Dakota portion, $1.04 billion in the Iowa portion, and $516 million in the Illinois portion. {{cite news | url = http://www.daplpipelinefacts.com/docs-dapl/08092016/DAPL_FactSheet33-8_09_16.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161223183437/http://www.daplpipelinefacts.com/docs-dapl/08092016/DAPL_FactSheet33-8_09_16.pdf |archive-date=December 23, 2016 | title = Dakota Access Fact Sheet | publisher = Dakota Access, LLC | accessdate = 2016-12-05}} Of this, $189 million would be paid to landowners. [[Energy Transfer Partners]] has estimated that the pipeline would create between 12 and 15 permanent jobs and from 2,000 to 4,000 temporary jobs in Iowa. The $1.35 billion capital investment in Iowa was projected to generate $33 million [[sales tax]] in Iowa during construction and $30 million [[property tax]] in 2017.{{cite news | url = http://thegazette.com/subject/news/texas-energy-company-releases-more-details-on-pipeline-20141001|title=Texas energy company releases more details on pipeline | date=October 1, 2014| newspaper = Cedar Rapids Gazette |publisher=SourceMedia, Investcorp| first = Chelsea | last = Keenan|accessdate=December 4, 2014}} According to the ''Des Moines Register'', Energy Transfer hired "Strategic Economics Group" in West Des Moines to prepare this analysis.{{cite news| first = Donnelle | last = Eller |title=Pipeline could bring $1.1 billion to Iowa|url=http://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/money/business/2014/11/12/pipeline-bring-hundreds-millions-iowa/18899319/|accessdate=December 6, 2014| newspaper = Des Moines Register|date=November 12, 2014}} Dave Swenson, an [[Iowa State University]] economics professor, said that "a strong fraction of work will accumulate to out-of-state employers who will bring in their skilled labor and then subcontract what they can along the way" to local concerns.{{cite news| first = Donnelle | last = Eller |title=Unlikely allies join to fight pipeline project|url=http://www.press-citizen.com/story/money/agriculture/2014/12/04/pipeline-proposal-creates-unusual-allies/19866127/|accessdate=December 4, 2014|date=December 4, 2014}} ==Purpose== [[File:Pipeline on rails, Trempealeau Wisconsin (12859842853).jpg|thumb|Bakken Oil being shipped by rail in [[Trempealeau, Wisconsin]], a few feet from the Mississippi River.]] The ETP desires the pipeline to provide an outlet for oil to be transferred across the country and then sold to international countries and corporations.{{cn|date=April 2017}} Dakota Access, LLC's planning applications argued that the pipeline improves the overall safety to the public, would help the US to attain [[energy independence]], and is a more reliable and safer method of transport to refineries than rail or road. Proponents have argued that the pipeline will free up railroads, which will allow farmers to ship more Midwest grain. About 70% of Bakken oil is transported by rail because of pipeline limitations.{{cite news |url= http://www.gmtoday.com/news/local_stories/2015/03062015-freight-train-carrying-crude-oil-derails-near-Illinois-city.asp |title= Illinois oil train derailment involved safer tank cars |agency= Associated Press |publisher= gmtoday.com |date= March 6, 2015 |accessdate= December 4, 2016 |quote= As of June of last year, BNSF was hauling 32 Bakken oil trains per week through the surrounding Jo Daviess County, according to information disclosed to Illinois emergency officials. ... According to the Association of American Railroads, oil shipments by rail jumped from 9,500 carloads in 2008 to 500,000 in 2014, driven by a boom in the Bakken oil patch of North Dakota and Montana, where pipeline limitations force 70 percent of the crude to move by rail.}} {{as of|July 2014}} Bakken shale oil was transported through nine Iowa counties exclusively via three [[freight train]]s per week.{{cite news |url= http://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/news/politics/iowa-politics-insider/2014/07/07/iowa-bakken-crude-oil--trains/12293733/ |title= Bakken oil trains run through Iowa |newspaper= The Des Moines Register |first= William |last= Petroski |date= July 7, 2014 |accessdate= December 4, 2016}} As of June 2014, 32 trains per week carrying Bakken oil traveled through [[Jo Daviess County, Illinois|Jo Daviess County]] in northwestern Illinois. Rail offers greater flexibility and adaptability and has had fewer spill volume per Billion-Ton-Miles, but costs significantly more than pipeline transportation and, similar to pipeline, still requires additional investment.{{cite report |title= U.S. Rail Transportation of Crude Oil: Background and Issues for Congress |url= https://fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/R43390.pdf |author= John Frittelli |author2=Anthony Andrews |author3=Paul W. Parfomak |author4= Robert Pirog |author5=Jonathan L. Ramseur |author6= Michael Ratner |publisher= Congressional Research Service |date= April 26, 2014 |accessdate= December 4, 2016 | archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20140328195423/http://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/R43390.pdf |archivedate= 2014-03-28}} ==Ownership== Dakota Access, LLC, owns 75% of the pipeline while Phillips 66 owns a 25% stake. {{Cite news | title = Energy Transfer (ETP) Reveals Bakken Pipeline Open Season | website = zacks.com | publisher = Zacks Equity Research | date = 2016-08-18 | url = https://www.zacks.com/stock/news/228509/energy-transfer-etp-reveals-bakken-pipeline-open-season | accessdate = 2016-12-12}} Energy Transfer Partners LP and [[Sunoco|Sunoco Logistic Partners LP]] owns together 51% and MarEn Bakken Company, the joint venture of [[Enbridge]] (75%) and [[Marathon Petroleum]], owns 49% of the Dakota Access, LLC. It gives the following indirect stakes in the pipeline: * Energy Transfer Partners LP and Sunoco Logistic Partners LP together – 38.2% * Enbridge – 27.6% * Phillips 66 – 25% * Marathon Petroleum – 9.2% Energy Transfer Partners and Sunoco Logistic Partners, both subsidiaries of [[Energy Transfer Equity]] LP, has announced their merger. {{Cite news | title = Is There Value In Sunoco Logistics' Merger With Energy Transfer Partners? | first = Claire | last = Poole | newspaper = [[Forbes]] | date = 2016-11-21 | url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/clairepoole/2016/11/21/is-there-value-in-sunoco-logistics-merger-with-energy-transfer-partners/#19b01419443e | accessdate = 2016-12-05}} Bakken Holdings Company and Phillips 66 also co-own another part of the Bakken system, the [[Energy Transfer Crude Oil Pipeline]] which runs from Patoka to storage terminals in [[Nederland, Texas]]. == Financing == The pipeline project costs $3.78 billion, of which $2.5 billion has been financed by loans, while the rest of the capital would be raised by the sale of a 49% stake in Dakota Access, LLC (36.8% indirect stake in the pipeline) to Enbridge and Marathon Petroleum. {{Cite news | title = Energy Transfer Partners, Sunoco Logistics Announced Stake Sale | first = Kurt | last = Gallon | work = Market Realist | date = 2016-08-08 | url = http://marketrealist.com/2016/08/energy-transfer-partners-sunoco-logistics-announced-stake-sale/ | accessdate = 2016-11-11}} The loans have been provided by a group of 17 banks, including [[Citibank]], [[Wells Fargo]], [[BNP Paribas]], [[SunTrust]], [[Royal Bank of Scotland]], [[Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi]], [[Mizuho Bank]], [[TD Securities]], [[ABN AMRO Capital]], [[ING Bank]], [[DNB ASA]], [[ICBC]], [[Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation|SMBC Nikko Securities]] and [[Société Générale]].{{cite web|title=Who's Investing in the Dakota Access Pipeline? Meet the Banks Financing Attacks on Protesters|url=http://www.democracynow.org/2016/9/6/whos_investing_in_the_dakota_access|website=Democracy Now!|accessdate=November 8, 2016|date=September 6, 2016}} Due to protests against the pipeline, the Norwegian bank DNB ASA announced in November 2016 to use its position as a lender of over $342 million credit "to encourage a more constructive process to find solutions to the conflict that has arisen."{{cite web|title=Norway's biggest bank may reconsider Dakota Access funding|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/business/dakota-access-bank-dnb-1.3841739|website=CBC News|accessdate=November 8, 2016|date=November 8, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Geiger|first1=Julianne|title=Another Setback For DAPL As Norwegian Bank Rethinks Funding|url=http://oilprice.com/Latest-Energy-News/World-News/Another-Setback-For-DAPL-As-Norwegian-Rethinks-Funding.html|website=oilprice.com|accessdate=November 8, 2016|date=November 7, 2016}} In February 2017, [[Seattle, Washington]]'s city council unanimously voted to not renew its contract with [[Wells Fargo]] "in a move that cites the bank's role as a lender to the Dakota Access Pipeline project as well as its "creation of millions of bogus accounts" and saying the bidding process for its next banking partner will involve "social responsibility." The City Council in [[Davis, California]], took a similar action voting unanimously to find a new bank to handle its accounts by the end of 2017.{{Cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/08/514133514/two-cities-vote-to-pull-more-than-3-billion-from-wells-fargo-over-dakota-pipelin |title=2 Cities To Pull More Than $3 Billion From Wells Fargo Over Dakota Access Pipeline |last=Chappell |first=Bill |date=February 8, 2017}}2 Cities To Pull More Than $3 Billion From Wells Fargo Over Dakota Access Pipeline In March 2017, ING sold its stake in the loan, while retaining a potential risk in case of non-payment under the loan.{{cite press release|title=ING has sold its stake in Dakota Access pipeline loan|url=https://www.ing.com/Newsroom/All-news/ING-has-sold-its-stake-in-Dakota-Access-pipeline-loan.htm|publisher = [[ING Bank]]| date = March 21, 2017 | accessdate = June 10, 2017}}{{cite news | title = Dakota Access pipeline: ING sells stake in major victory for divestment push | url = https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/mar/21/dakota-access-pipeline-ing-sells-stake-loan-standing-rock | first = Julia Carrie | last = Wong | newspaper = The Guardian | date = March 21, 2017 | accessdate = June 10, 2017}} ==Route== [[File:Bakken Wells 2013.png|thumb|Map of Bakken wells in the Dakotas]] The pipeline route runs from the northwestern North Dakota [[Bakken formation|Bakken]] and [[Three Forks Group|Three Forks]] sites. It starts in [[Stanley, North Dakota]], and travels in a southeastward direction to end at the oil tank farm near [[Patoka, Illinois]].{{cite news | url= http://www.amestrib.com/news/energy-transfer-phillips-66-partner-iowa-pipeline?start=2 | title=Energy Transfer, Phillips 66 partner on Iowa pipeline| newspaper = Ames Tribune| first = Gavin | last = Aronsen |date=October 28, 2014}} It crosses 50 counties in four states. {{Cite news | title = 2 years of opposition, 1,172 miles of pipe, 1.3 million Facebook check-ins. The numbers to know about the Standing Rock protests | first1 = Alene | last1 = Tchekmedyian | first2 = Melissa | last2 = Etehad | newspaper = Los Angeles Times | date = 2016-11-01 | url = http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-standing-rock-numbers-20161101-story.html | accessdate = 2016-12-03}} In North Dakota, the {{convert|346|mi|km|adj=on}} route traverses seven counties. The project consists of {{convert|143|mi}} of oil gathering pipelines and {{convert|200|mi|km|0}} of larger transmission pipeline. The route starts with a terminal in the [[Stanley, North Dakota|Stanley]] area, and runs west with five more terminals in Ramberg Station, [[Epping, North Dakota|Epping]], [[Trenton, North Dakota|Trenton]], [[Watford City, North Dakota|Watford City]] and Johnsons Corner before becoming a transmission line going through [[Williston, North Dakota|Williston]], the [[Watford City, North Dakota|Watford City]] area, south of [[Bismarck, North Dakota|Bismarck]], and crossing the [[Missouri River]] again north of [[Cannon Ball, North Dakota|Cannon Ball]].{{cite news|first = Mike | last = Nowatzki|title='Stealth' North Dakota Bakken oil pipeline project faces fight|url=http://www.twincities.com/2014/08/29/stealth-north-dakota-bakken-oil-pipeline-project-faces-fight/|accessdate=December 4, 2014|work=Pioneer Press|date=August 30, 2014}} It also includes six tank farm locations, one electric pump station. In the early stages of route planning, it was proposed laying the pipeline {{convert|10|mi}} northeast of [[Bismarck, North Dakota]]. {{Cite news | title = The Conflicts Along 1,172 Miles of the Dakota Access Pipeline | first1 = Gregor | last1 = Aisch | first2 = K.K. Rebecca | last2 = Lai | newspaper = The New York Times | date = 2016-11-01 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/11/23/us/dakota-access-pipeline-protest-map.html | accessdate = 2017-03-17}} {{Cite news | title = Pipeline route plan first called for crossing north of Bismarck | first1 = Amy | last1 = Dalrymple | newspaper = The Bismarck Tribune | date = 2016-08-18 | url = http://bismarcktribune.com/news/state-and-regional/pipeline-route-plan-first-called-for-crossing-north-of-bismarck/article_64d053e4-8a1a-5198-a1dd-498d386c933c.html | accessdate = 2017-03-17 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20161101185338/http://bismarcktribune.com/news/state-and-regional/pipeline-route-plan-first-called-for-crossing-north-of-bismarck/article_64d053e4-8a1a-5198-a1dd-498d386c933c.html | archivedate = November 1, 2016 | df = mdy-all }} The Bismarck route was {{convert|11|mi}} longer and was rejected by on the basis its potential threat to Bismarck's water supply. It was rejected by the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers]] (USACE) in an early environmental assessment before submitting a request to the [[North Dakota Public Service Commission]] (NDPSC) for a permit. {{Cite news | title = Why a Previously Proposed Route for the Dakota Access Pipeline Was Rejected | first1 = Catherine | last1 = Thorbecke | work = ABC News | date = 2016-11-03 | url = http://abcnews.go.com/US/previously-proposed-route-dakota-access-pipeline-rejected/story?id=43274356 | accessdate = 2017-03-17}} This decision was described by some activists like [[Jesse Jackson]] as [[environmental racism]]. The change of the route put the pipeline into the existing pipeline corridor parallel to the already existing [[Northern Border Pipeline]], a natural gas pipeline built in 1982.{{cite web | url= http://www.globalresearch.ca/standing-rock-2017-and-the-dakota-access-pipeline-dapl-the-fight-is-not-over/5566609 | title = Standing Rock 2017 and the Dakota Access Pipeline (DAPL): The Fight is Not Over | first = Makia | last = Freeman | publisher = The Freedom Articles | via = [[Centre for Research on Globalization]] | date = 2016-01-04 | accessdate = 2017-01-08}} The Dakota Access pipeline selected a "nearly identical route" and planned to cross the Missouri River near the same point.{{cite news |url= http://bigstory.ap.org/article/ee3f4c94995a4d5fa740cc8d115a8f8b/if-dakota-access-pipeline-were-move-where |title= If Dakota Access pipeline were to move, where? |first = James | last = MacPherson | agency = Associated Press | date = November 3, 2016 | accessdate = November 27, 2016}} The plans call for the pipeline to be directionally bored so that it will not come in contact with the Missouri River. It is planned to be "as deep as {{convert|90|ft|m|1}}" below the riverbed.{{cite news |url= http://www.kfyrtv.com/content/news/ND-PSC-says-Dakota-Access-Pipeline-will-not-come-into-physical-contact-with-Missouri-River-390640012.html |title= ND PSC says Dakota Access Pipeline will not come into physical contact with Missouri River |first= Bo |last= Evans |publisher= KFYR TV |date= August 18, 2016 |accessdate=November 27, 2016 }}{{cite report |url= http://cdm16021.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/ref/collection/p16021coll7/id/2801 |title= Environmental assessment: Dakota Access Pipeline Project, crossings of flowage easements and federal lands | publisher= U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, Omaha District |author= Dakota Access Pipeline |page= 385 |accessdate=November 27, 2016}} The pipeline does not cross the Sioux land but by a point it is only about {{convert|500|ft|m}} from the Standing Rock reservation. In South Dakota, the pipeline travels {{convert|274|mi}} through 12 counties: [[Campbell County, South Dakota|Campbell]], [[McPherson County, South Dakota|McPherson]], [[Edmunds County, South Dakota|Edmunds]], [[Faulk County, South Dakota|Faulk]] and [[Spink County, South Dakota|Spink]].{{cite news|author1=Connie Sieh Groop|title=Bakken pipeline would cross northeastern South Dakota to get to Illinois|url=http://www.aberdeennews.com/news/local/bakken-pipeline-would-cross-northeastern-south-dakota-to-get-to/article_03e0474c-7931-5b1c-8134-0a34f539ff13.html|accessdate=December 4, 2014|work=Aberdeen News|publisher=Schurz Communications|date=September 15, 2014}} The system includes one electric pump station. [[File:Dakota Access Pipe Line, Central Iowa.jpg|thumb|Dakota Access Pipeline being built in central Iowa]] In Iowa, the pipeline extends about {{convert|347|mi}} diagonally through 18 Iowa counties: [[Lyon County, Iowa|Lyon]], [[Sioux County, Iowa|Sioux]], [[O'Brien County, Iowa|O'Brien]], [[Cherokee County, Iowa|Cherokee]], [[Buena Vista County, Iowa|Buena Vista]] [[Sac County, Iowa|Sac]], [[Calhoun County, Iowa|Calhoun]], [[Webster County, Iowa|Webster]], [[Boone County, Iowa|Boone]], [[Story County, Iowa|Story]] (which will have a pumping station), [[Polk County, Iowa|Polk]], [[Jasper County, Iowa|Jasper]], [[Mahaska County, Iowa|Mahaska]] [[Keokuk, Iowa|Keokuk]], [[Wapello, Iowa|Wapello]], [[Jefferson County, Iowa|Jefferson]], [[Van Buren County, Iowa|Van Buren]], and [[Lee County, Iowa|Lee]].{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} The system includes one electric pump station. In Illinois, the {{convert|177|mi|km|adj=on}} route traverses 12 counties. == History == === Planning, 2014-2016 === [[File:Sioux-treaty-lands.png|thumb|Fort Laramie Treaty boundary which [[David Archambault II|Dave Archambault II]] invoked, opposing any pipeline construction within that area.{{cite AV media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZlwdtnZXmtY?t=5m48|title=Sept 30th DAPL meeting with SRST|date=September 30, 2014|publisher=Standing Rock Sioux Tribe|time=5:48|quote=(evocation of treaty boundaries: Fort Laramie Treaties (1851 and 1868) and standing resolution from 2012). Afterward, Chuck Frey (VP of ETP) makes a presentation of the DAPL project.|via=Youtube|accessdate=November 27, 2016}}]] Energy Transfer Partners approved and announced the pipeline project on June 25, 2014. {{Cite press release | title = Energy Transfer (ETP) Reveals Bakken Pipeline Open Season | publisher = Energy Transfer Partners | date = 2014-06-25 | url = http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20140625006184/en/Energy-Transfer-Announces-Crude-Oil-Pipeline-Project | accessdate = 2016-12-12 | via = [[Business Wire]]}} In October 2014, Phillips 66 acquired 25% stake in the project. In September 2014, Dakota Access held an initial informational meeting with the Standing Rock Sioux Tribal Council. Informational meetings for South Dakota and Illinois landowners were held in October 2014, and starting on December 1, 2014, in each of the affected counties in Iowa.{{cite news| first = Rod | last = Boshart | newspaper = [[The Gazette (Cedar Rapids)|The Gazette]] | title = | url = http://www.thegazette.com/subject/news/iowa-oil-pipeline-meetings-start-today-20141201 | date = December 1, 2014 | accessdate = 2016-12-14}} Meetings in [[Fort Madison, Iowa|Fort Madison]], [[Sioux Center, Iowa|Sioux Center]], [[Oskaloosa, Iowa|Oskaloosa]] and [[Storm Lake, Iowa|Storm Lake]] brought out 200 to 350 people at each venue and in each one some attendees expressed their opposition to the pipeline.{{cite news|author1=Joyce Russell|title=Landowners Question Bakken Pipeline|url=http://iowapublicradio.org/post/landowners-question-bakken-pipeline|accessdate=December 3, 2014|work=Iowa Public Radio|publisher=NPR.org|date=December 2, 2014}}{{cite news| agency =Associated Press|title= Concerns voiced at oil pipeline meeting in S.E. Iowa|date=December 1, 2014|url= http://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/news/2014/12/01/pipeline-meetings-concerns/19762063/}}{{cite news| first = Rachael | last = Krause |title=Hundreds Pack Inside Sioux Center Meeting On Proposed Dakota Access Pipeline Project|url=http://www.siouxlandmatters.com/news/local-news/hundreds-pack-inside-sioux-center-meeting-on-propo | accessdate=December 4, 2014|work=SiouxLandMatters.com|publisher=Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc.|date=December 1, 2014}}{{cite news|author1=Mark Tauscheck|title=Iowans pack meeting on new oil pipeline|url=http://www.kcci.com/article/iowans-pack-meeting-on-new-oil-pipeline/6900237|accessdate=December 4, 2014|work=KCCI-TV.|publisher=Des Moines Hearst Television Inc.|date=December 3, 2014}} A webinar for [[Brown County, Illinois|Brown]] and [[Hancock County, Illinois]] took place in February 2015.{{cite web|title=Two county Farm Bureaus to host crude oil pipeline webinar|url=http://farmweeknow.com/story-two-county-fbs-host-crude-oil-pipeline-webinar-1-123636|publisher=Illinois Farm Bureau|accessdate=March 3, 2015|date=February 6, 2015}} On October 29, 2014 Dakota Access submitted the project to the [[Iowa Utilities Board]] (IUB),{{cite web|url=https://efs.iowa.gov/efs/ShowDocketSummary.do?docketNumber=HLP-2014-0001|title=Docket Summary for Docket HLP-2014-0001 |author=[[Iowa Utilities Board]] |date=n.d.|accessdate=December 1, 2014}} after Iowa Governor [[Terry Branstad]] rejected pleas from a coalition of Iowa community and environmental activists who asked him to block plans.{{cite news|url=http://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/news/politics/iowa-politics-insider/2014/10/14/branstad-wont-stop-iowa-bakken-oil-pipeline/17246713/|accessdate=December 1, 2014|title=Branstad won't stop Bakken oil pipeline through Iowa|date=October 14, 2014 | first = William | last = Petroski | newspaper = Des Moines Register}} In December 2014 Dakota Access submitted an application for a permit from the North Dakota Public Service Commission for the proposed route.{{Cite web | url = http://www.psc.nd.gov/database/documents/14-0842/001-030.pdf | title = North Dakota Public Service Commission Iowa fields contain a lot of [[tile drainage|drain tiles]], which can be damaged. The pipeline company said they would repair any tile damaged during construction and place the pipeline 2 feet (.6 m) below drainage tiles. Stop the Bakken Pipeline - Iowa (23936434044).jpg|thumb|Highway sign objecting to the pipeline in Iowa]] Landowners across Iowa have expressed concern about the implications of allowing the state to use eminent domain to condemn privately owned land, particularly agricultural land, on behalf of a company that has not demonstrated any substantial public benefit to the residents of Iowa.{{cite news |last1=Petroski |first1=William |title=296 Iowa landowners decline Bakken pipeline |url=http://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/news/local/government/2016/02/09/296-iowa-landowners-decline-bakken-pipeline/80085982/ |newspaper=Des Moines Register |date=February 9, 2016| accessdate=2016-11-06}} In March 2015, a ''[[Des Moines Register]]'' poll found that while 57% of Iowans supported the Dakota Access Pipeline, 74% were opposed to the use of eminent domain condemnation on behalf of a private corporation.{{cite web|title=Iowa Poll: Iowans back energy projects, but oppose eminent domain|url=http://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/news/politics/2015/03/01/iowa-poll-bakken-wind-energy/24229261/|website=www.desmoinesregister.com|date=2 March 2015| accessdate=2 March 2015}} The Iowa chapter of the [[Sierra Club]] was "worried about the rights of landowners [...] concerned about [their] Dakota Access LLCs economic projections and whether there are really any benefits to Iowa." For pipelines, [[eminent domain]] is most often invoked to grant a legal "[[right of way]]" [[easement]] for a certain tract of land with a parcel owned by a private landowner(s) as is necessary for the pipeline to pass through the parcels along its route. While many people believe the invocation of "eminent domain" inherently means land is being taken away completely from landowners,{{cite web|url=https://thinkprogress.org/for-profit-pipelines-are-growing-and-so-are-eminent-domain-battles-2b8beee7af3c#.o0yoa06q4|title=For-Profit Pipelines Are Growing And So Are Eminent Domain Battles|first=Alejandro Dávila|last=Fragoso|date=June 7, 2016|publisher=|accessdate=December 14, 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2016/05/10/39687/|title=Invoking power of eminent domain, gas industry runs roughshod over private property|publisher=|accessdate=December 14, 2016}} landowners do retain ownership of property affected by a pipeline right of way—however, those landowners lose certain rights to the portion of their property encumbered by the easement, including the right to freely use that portion of their property. Because [[eminent domain in the United States|US law]] requires landowners receive "just compensation" when eminent domain is invoked, landowners whose property rights are affected by the pipeline are compensated for the long-term use of their land, and they are paid for the loss of the current crop on farmland, replacement of fences, and re-seeding of grass.[http://pstrust.org/docs/sample_row.pdf Sample of an actual right-of-way agreement; Pipeline Safety Trust.]{{cite web|url=http://pstrust.org/about-pipelines1/landowners-guide-to-pipelines/|title=Landowner’s Guide to Pipelines - Pipeline Safety Trust|publisher=|accessdate=December 14, 2016}} When a landowner voluntarily enters an easement agreement granting a right of way for the pipeline in exchange for compensation, the easement is called a voluntary easement. This easement allows for construction of the pipeline to cross the Mni Sose. {{Cite news|url=http://sacredstonecamp.org/blog/2017/2/7/breaking-army-corps-to-grant-dakota-access-easement#army|title=This Is The #NoDAPL Last Stand|work=Sacred Stone Camp - Iŋyaŋ Wakháŋagapi Othí|access-date=2017-03-03|language=en-US}} ===Tribal opposition=== The [[Meskwaki]] tribe opposes the pipeline for numerous reasons; tribal chairwoman Judith Bender told the Iowa Utilities Board that she is concerned that the pipeline could be used as a replacement if the [[Keystone XL pipeline]] is not built.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2015/03/16/meskwaki-tribe-opposes-bakken-pipeline/24834269/|title=Meskwaki tribe opposes Bakken oil pipeline through Iowa|last=Petroski|first=William|date=March 16, 2015|accessdate=April 8, 2015|newspaper=USA Today}} The Standing Rock Sioux and the [[Cheyenne River Sioux]] tribes have also stated their opposition to the Dakota Access Pipeline on the grounds that the pipeline and its construction threatens the tribe's "way of life, [their] water, people, and land".{{Cite news|url=https://drive.google.com/viewerng/viewer?url=http://standingrock.org/data/upfiles/media/2121_001.pdf&key=856bb34d6fa64f9cb99f3975386b1c13|title=Call to Action of Indigenous People's|last=Archambault II|first=Dave|date=August 15, 2016|work=Standing Rock Sioux Tribe|access-date=November 15, 2016|via=Stand with Standing Rock}} In September 2014, Standing Rock Chairman [[David Archambault II|Dave Archambault II]] indicated the tribe's opposition to any pipeline within treaty boundaries encompassing "North Dakota, Montana, Wyoming and South Dakota."{{cite AV media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZlwdtnZXmtY?t=5m48|title=Sept 30th DAPL meeting with SRST|date=September 30, 2014|publisher=Standing Rock Sioux Tribe|time=5:48|quote=(evocation of treaty boundaries: Fort Laramie Treaties (1851 and 1868) and standing resolution from 2012). Afterward, Chuck Frey (VP of ETP) makes a presentation of the DAPL project.|via=Youtube|accessdate=November 27, 2016}} The decision to reroute the pipeline closer to the reservation was described by [[Jesse Jackson]] and other critics as "environmental racism".{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/previously-proposed-route-dakota-access-pipeline-rejected/story?id=43274356|title=Why Previously Proposed Route for Dakota Access Pipeline Was Rejected|date=4 November 2016|website=ABC News|last1=Thorbecke|first1=Catherine|accessdate=6 November 2016}} Saying that "the Corps effectively wrote off the tribe's concerns and ignored the pipeline’s impacts to sacred sites and culturally important landscapes," the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe has sued the USACE in the [[United States District Court for the District of Columbia]], accusing the agency of violating the [[National Historic Preservation Act of 1966|National Historic Preservation Act]] and other laws, and seeking [[Declaratory judgment|declaratory]] and [[Injunction|injunctive]] relief to stop the pipeline.{{cite journal|date=July 27, 2016|title=Standing Rock Sioux Tribe v. These surveys were carried out under the direction of the USACE, in compliance with the [[National Historic Preservation Act of 1966|National Historic Preservation Act]] (NHPA).{{cite web|url=http://mapabing.org/2016/09/09/dapl-is-the-biggest-issue-in-public-archaeology-right-now/|title=DAPL is the biggest issue in Public Archaeology right now|work=Master of Arts in Public Archaeology at Binghamton University|date=2016-09-09|access-date=2017-05-09}} The NHPA requires consideration of archaeological sites and traditional cultural properties.{{cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/nr/publications/bulletins/nrb38/nrb38%20introduction.htm#tcp|title=Introduction: Guidelines for Evaluating and Documenting Traditional Cultural Properties | journal=National Register of Historic Places Bulletin |issue=38|last=Jeff|first=Joeckel|date=2001-11-28|access-date=2017-05-09}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.fema.gov/national-historic-preservation-act-1966-amended-2000|title=National Historic Preservation Act, 1966 as Amended (2000) |publisher=[[Federal Emergency Management Agency]]|access-date=2017-05-09}} The initial survey showed 149 sites and the pipeline was subsequently moved to avoid 140 of them.{{cite news|url=https://theconversation.com/how-the-archaeological-review-behind-the-dakota-access-pipeline-went-wrong-67815|title=How the archaeological review behind the Dakota Access Pipeline went wrong|last=Colwell|first=Chip|work=The Conversation|access-date=2017-05-09}}{{cite web|url=http://oldarchives.courthousenews.com/2016/09/09/pipeline-will-proceed-despite-tribal-protests.htm|title=Pipeline Will Proceed Despite Tribal Protests|work=Courthouse News Service|date=2016-09-09|access-date=2017-05-09}} The Advisory Council on Historic Preservation, which oversees compliance with the NHPA, raised two primary concerns to the USACE about the surveys.{{cite web|url=https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/3036069-Ex-32-ACHP-Objection-Letter-DAPL.html|title=Ex-32-ACHP-Objection-Letter-DAPL|last=Nelson|first=Reid J.|website=www.documentcloud.org|date=2016-05-19|access-date=2017-05-09}} They criticized the scope of the investigation, which defined each water crossing as a separate project, and therefore failed to consider the pipeline as a whole. They also criticized the lack of tribal involvement in the surveys. Tribal consultants help archaeologists identify sites that may be harder to see within the archaeological record, such as traditional cultural properties. A traditional cultural property is a property whose "significance derived from the role the property plays in a community’s historically rooted beliefs, customs, and practices." The USACE reached out to the Standing Rock Sioux on several occasions for consultation, but were denied. The Sioux refused to participate unless they could consult on the whole pipeline. One instance of tribal consultation at Lake Oahe identified several cultural sites and a cemetery that the USACE previously failed to note. On September 2, 2016 Tim Mentz, a former Historic Preservation Officer for the Standing Rock Sioux, testified in DC District Court that 27 graves and 82 sacred sites were to be disturbed by the Cannonball river section of the pipeline.{{Cite news|url=http://whowhatwhy.org/2016/09/19/grave-matters-pipeline-controversy/|title=Grave Matters in Pipeline Controversy|date=2016-09-19|work=WhoWhatWhy|access-date=2017-05-09}} That weekend this area was bulldozed.{{cite web|url=http://www.democracynow.org/2016/9/6/did_the_dakota_access_pipeline_company|title=Did the Dakota Access Pipeline Company Deliberately Destroy Sacred Sioux Burial Sites?|work=Democracy Now!|date=2016-09-06|access-date=2017-05-09}}{{cite web|url=https://indiancountrymedianetwork.com/history/events/state-commissioned-archaeological-study-denies-standing-rock-experts-a-voice/|title=State-Commissioned Archaeological Study Denies Standing Rock Experts a Voice|work=Indian Country Today|date=2016-10-06|access-date=2017-05-09}} On September 21, 2016, 1,281 anthropologists, archaeologists, museum officials, and others signed and released a letter in support of the tribal community, calling for further study of the area to be affected by the pipeline in South Dakota.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/22/arts/design/north-dakota-oil-pipeline-museum-officials-and-archaeologists-sign-letter.html|title=Museum Officials and Archaeologists Sign Petition Against N. They found that only four stone features would be directly impacted by the pipeline. However, many are still concerned about the cumulative effect the project may have on sites that lie outside the 150 ft corridor. Jon Eagle, a Historic Preservation Officer for the tribe, was invited to participate in the evaluation on Sept. 23, but was not allowed access to the areas of the corridor on private property. The tribe insists that evidence was destroyed by the construction company, as grading had gone on in the area previously. ===Political ties=== According to his federal disclosure forms, filed in May 2016, President [[Donald Trump]] held between $15,000 and $50,000 in stock in Energy Transfer Partners – down from $500,000 to $1 million in 2015 – and between $100,000 and $250,000 in Phillips 66.
